content.question: Researchers are studying populations of two squirrels, the eastern gray and the western gray. For the eastern gray squirrel, about 22 percent of the population weighs over 0.5 kilogram <math alttext="k g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>. For the western gray squirrel, about 36 percent of the population weighs over 0.5 <math alttext="k g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow></math>. A random sample of 60 squirrels will be selected from the population of eastern gray squirrels, and a random sample of 120 squirrels will be selected from the population of western gray squirrels. What is the mean of the sampling distribution of the difference in sample proportions (eastern minus western) ?

choices.label: <math alttext="the square root of the fraction 0.22 times 0.78 over 120, end fraction, plus the fraction 0.36 times 0.64 over 60, end root" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msqrt><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>0.22</mn><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0.78</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>120</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>0.36</mn><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0.64</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>60</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="the square root of the fraction 0.22 times 0.78 over 60, end fraction, plus the fraction 0.36 times 0.64 over 120, end root" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msqrt><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>0.22</mn><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0.78</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>60</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>0.36</mn><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0.64</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>120</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mstyle></math>

topic.text: 5.6: Sampling Distributions for Differences in Sample Proportions

skill.text: Skill 3.B: Determine parameters for probability distributions.
